Magoosh Free Trial.meaning_1: noun: A sample of lesson videos and practice questions to see if Magoosh is right for you. Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Magoosh Free Trial.sentence_1: Rachel tried the Magoosh free trial to determine if the premium Magoosh service was worth purchasing.

derivative.meaning_1: adjective: not original but drawing strongly on something already in existence, especially in reference to a creative product (e.g. music, writing, poetry etc.).
derivative.sentence_1: Because the movies were utterly derivative of other popular movies, they did well at the box office.

refractory.meaning_1: adjective: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
refractory.sentence_1: Used to studious high school students, Martha was unprepared for the refractory Kindergarteners who neither sat still nor listened to a single word she said.

derive.sentence_1: Many words in the English language are derived from Latin, including the word "derive."
derive.sentence_2: From the multiple set of footprints in the living room, the investigator derived an important clue: Sheila was not alone in the room at the time of the murder.
derive.meaning_2: verb: reason by deduction; establish by deduction
derive.meaning_1: verb: come from; be connected by a relationship of blood, for example

treacherous.sentence_1: Even though Jesse James was an outlaw, his killer, Robert Ford, is remembered more for his treacherous actions than for eliminating a criminal and murderer.
treacherous.sentence_2: The bridge built from twine and vine is treacherous to walk across, and so I think I will stay put right here.

rudimentary.meaning_1: adjective: being in the earliest stages of development; being or involving basic facts or principles
rudimentary.sentence_1: I would love to be able to present a fully polished proposal to the board, but right now, our plans for the product are still in the most rudimentary stages.

frustrate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
frustrate.meaning_1: verb: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires) of
frustrate.sentence_1: I thought I would finish writing the paper by lunchtime, but a number of urgent interruptions served to frustrate my plan.

jubilant.meaning_1: adjective: full of high-spirited delight because of triumph or success
jubilant.sentence_1: My hardwork paid off, and I was jubilant to receive a perfect score on the GRE.

ameliorate.sentence_1: "Three Cups of Tea" tells the story of western man who hopes to ameliorate poverty and the lack of education in Afghanistan.

juxtapose.meaning_1: verb: place side by side for contrast
juxtapose.sentence_1: The appeal of her paintings comes from a classical style which is juxtaposed with modern themes.

immutable.meaning_1: adjective: not able to be changed
immutable.sentence_1: Taxes are one of the immutable laws of the land, so there is no use arguing about paying them.

negligible.meaning_1: adjective: so small as to be meaningless; insignificant
negligible.sentence_1: The GRE tests cumulative knowledge, so if you cram the night before it is, at best, likely to only have a negligible impact on your score.

supplant.meaning_1: verb: take the place or move into the position of
supplant.sentence_1: For many, a cell phone has supplanted a traditional phone; in fact, most 20-somethings don't even have a traditional phone anymore.

eminent.meaning_1: adjective: standing above others in quality or position
eminent.sentence_1: Shakespeare is an eminent author in the English language, but I find his writing uninteresting and melodramatic.

unequivocal.meaning_1: adjective: admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding; having only one meaning or interpretation and leading to only one conclusion
unequivocal.sentence_1: The President's first statement on the subject was vague and open to competing interpretations, so when he spoke to Congress about the same subject later, he was careful to make his position completely unequivocal.

vilify.sentence_1: Todd was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about Barbara, but Barbara did not hesitate to vilify Todd.

itinerant.meaning_1: adjective: traveling from place to place to work
itinerant.sentence_1: Doctors used to be itinerant, traveling between patients' homes.

subsume.sentence_1: The rogue wave quickly subsumed the pier and boardwalk, destroying everything in its path.
subsume.sentence_2: Don Quixote of La Mancha subsumes all other modern novels, demonstrating modern literary devices and predating even the idea of a postmodern, metanarrative.
subsume.meaning_2: verb: consider (an instance of something) as part of a general rule or principle

tantamount.meaning_1: adjective: being essentially equal to something
tantamount.sentence_1: In many situations, remaining silent is tantamount to admitting guilt, so speak to prove your innocence.

precocious.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by or characteristic of exceptionally early development or maturity (especially in mental aptitude)
precocious.sentence_1: Though only seven years old, she was a precocious chess prodigy, able to beat players twice her age.

spurious.sentence_1: When listening to a politician speak, it is hard to distinguish the spurious claims from the authentic ones.

guileless.sentence_1: At first I thought my niece was guileless, but I then found myself buying her ice cream every time we passed a shop.

magnanimous.meaning_1: adjective: noble and generous in spirit, especially towards a rival or someone less powerful
magnanimous.sentence_1: He was a great sportsman: in defeat he was complimentary and in victory he was magnanimous.

apathy.meaning_1: noun: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
apathy.sentence_1: Widespread apathy among voters led to a very small turnout on election day.

tenacious.sentence_1: Even the most tenacious advocates for gun ownership must admit some of the dangers that firearms present.

panache.sentence_1: Jim, with his typical panache, came to the wedding reception with a top hat and cane.

quotidian.meaning_1: adjective: found in the ordinary course of events
quotidian.sentence_1: Phil gets so involved thinking about Aristotle's arguments that he totally forgets quotidian concerns, such as exercising and eating regularly.

delineate.sentence_1: After a brief summary of proper swimming technique, the coach delineated the specifics of each stroke, spending 30 minutes alone on the backstroke.

vehement.meaning_1: adjective: marked by extreme intensity of emotions or convictions
vehement.sentence_1: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.

forlorn.meaning_1: adjective: marked by or showing hopelessness
forlorn.sentence_1: After her third pet dog died, Marcia was simply forlorn: this time even the possibility of buying a new dog no longer held any joy.

eclectic.meaning_1: adjective: comprised of a variety of styles
eclectic.sentence_1: Joey was known for his eclectic tastes in music, one moment dancing to disco the next "air conducting" along to Beethoven's 9th symphony.

elucidate.meaning_1: verb: make clearer and easier to understand
elucidate.sentence_1: Youtube is great place to learn just about anything--an expert elucidates finer points so that even a complete novice can learn.

languid.meaning_1: adjective: not inclined towards physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
languid.sentence_1: As the sun beat down and the temperature climbed higher, we spent a languid week lying around the house.

staunch.meaning_1: adjective: firm and dependable especially in loyalty
staunch.sentence_1: No longer a staunch supporter of the movement, Todd now will openly question whether its goals are worthwhile.

jingoism.sentence_1: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

ascetic.sentence_1: His ascetic life is the main reason he inspired so many followers, especially since he gave up wealth and power to live in poverty.
ascetic.sentence_2: Historically, ascetics like Gandhi are often considered wise men partially because of their restraint.
ascetic.meaning_2: noun: one who practices great self-denial

travesty.meaning_1: noun: an absurd presentation of something; a mockery
travesty.sentence_1: What I expected to be an intelligent, nuanced historical documentary turned out to be a poorly-produced travesty of the form.

belligerent.meaning_1: adjective: characteristic of one eager to fight
belligerent.sentence_1: Tom said that he was arguing the matter purely for philosophical reasons, but his belligerent tone indicated an underlying anger about the issue.

contrive.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
contrive.meaning_1: verb: to pull off a plan or scheme, usually through skill or trickery
contrive.sentence_1: Despite a low GPA, he contrived to get into college, going so far as to write his own glowing letters of recommendation.

circumvent.meaning_1: verb: cleverly find a way out of one's duties or obligations
circumvent.sentence_1: One way of circumventing the GRE is to apply to a grad school that does not require GRE scores.

avaricious.sentence_1: Since avaricious desire is similar to gluttony or lust--sins of excess--it was listed as one of the seven deadly sins by the Catholic church.

insidious.meaning_1: adjective: working in a subtle but destructive way
insidious.sentence_1: Plaque is insidious: we cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.

mollify.meaning_1: verb: to make someone angry less angry; placate
mollify.sentence_1: In the morning, Janine was unable to mollify Harry, if he happened to become angry, unless he'd had his cup of coffee.

haughty.meaning_1: adjective: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy
haughty.sentence_1: The haughty manager didn't believe that any of his subordinates could ever have an insight as brilliant as his own.

disaffected.sentence_1: After watching his superior take rations from the soldiers, he quickly became disaffected and rebelled.

fallacious.meaning_1: adjective: of a belief that is based on faulty reasoning
fallacious.sentence_1: The widespread belief that Eskimos have forty different words for snow is fallacious, based on one false report.

heretic.meaning_1: noun: a person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field (not merely religion)
heretic.sentence_1: Though everybody at the gym told Mikey to do cardio before weights, Mikey was a heretic and always did the reverse.

denote.meaning_1: verb: be a sign or indication of; have as a meaning
denote.sentence_1: Even if the text is not visible, the red octagon denotes "stop" to all motorists in America.

ephemeral.meaning_1: adjective: lasting a very short time
ephemeral.sentence_1: The lifespan of a mayfly is ephemeral, lasting from a few hours to a couple of days.

abstain.meaning_1: verb: choose not to consume or take part in (particularly something enjoyable)
abstain.sentence_1: Considered a health nut, Jessica abstained from anything containing sugar--even chocolate.

incongruous.meaning_1: adjective: lacking in harmony or compatibility or appropriateness
incongruous.sentence_1: The vast economic inequality of modern society is incongruous with America's ideals.
